did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.unittitle: International Center for Transitional Justice (ICTJ) records 1981-2008
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: The International Center for Transitional Justice (ICTJ) is a non-profit organization that assists post-conflict, conflict, and democratic countries in pursuing accountability for mass atrocities and human rights abuses.

The International Center for Transitional Justice (ICTJ) Records include printed materials and publications, country files, staff files, audiovisual materials, a Mena survey, miscellaneous publications, institutional materials, CPU materials, Documentation Center materials, Historical Memory Project and Policymakers Retreat files, and other miscellaneous materials. This accession has not been processed.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: RESTRICTED: Access to the following series is restricted: Accession 2009-0193, Accession 2010-0111, and Accession 2010-0140. Please contact reference archivist for assistance.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], International Center for Transitional Justice Printed Materials, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The International Center for Transitional Justice Printed Materials were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2008-2009.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Encoded by Robert Carson, Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, April 2009; updated by Meghan Lyon, November 2009 and July 2010
Accessions 2008-0251, 2009-0193, 2010-0111, and 2010-0140 are described in this finding aid.
Descriptive sources and standards used to create this inventory: DACS, EAD, NCEAD guidelines, and local Style Guide.
This finding aid is NCEAD compliant.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The printed material files of the International Center for Transitional Justice span the years 1981 to 2008. Gathered by staff at the ICTJ as a resource file, the files house publications from the United States, Canada, and countries all over the world relating to peace processes and to the pursuit of legal reparations and reconciliation in areas of conflict involving human rights violations. Formats include annual reports, legal journals, human rights organization publications, many types of reports and white papers, conference proceedings, and newspapers, as well as some posters and other ephemera.

The files are arranged in two main series: General Files, which are subdivided into Annual Reports, Conference Files, Journal Issues, Other Printed Material, and Subject Files; and the Geographic Series, arranged into subdivisions for Africa, Asia, Europe, North America, and Latin America, then by individual countries in alphabetical order. There are also separately housed oversize Geographic Series materials, arranged in alphabetical order by country and described at the end of the main collection. Acquired as part of the Human Rights Archive at Duke University.

Accession (2009-0193) (76 lin. ft) has not been processed but makes up the majority of the collection's materials. Large components of this accession are African, Asian, European, and South American country files, as well as individual staff files for employees in a variety of ICTJ departments. Also included are audiovisual materials, a Mena survey, ICTJ and miscellaneous publications, institutional materials, CPU materials, Documentation Center materials, Historical Memory Project and Policymakers Retreat files, and other miscellaneous materials. This accession has not been processed, but materials have been described using a folder list below.
Accession (2010-0111) (2.0 lin. ft.) has not been processed. It includes electronic files and drives as well as audiovisual material from the ICTJ Iraq Tribunal. Materials have been described below.

Accession (2010-0140) (2.0 lin. ft.) has not been processed. It includes audiovisual material and electronic drives and discs, along with some handbooks and notes. Materials have been described below.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

scopecontent.p: Subdivided into the following subseries further described below: Annual Reports, Conference Files, Journal Issues, Other Printed Material, and Subject Area Files.

Contains reports published chiefly by U.S. non-profit organizations. Broadly speaking, topics concern human rights, economic development, and international law. In addition to the U.S. publications, there are some items originating from countries such as South Africa, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. Arranged chronologically by year.
Contains files from conferences concerning security, human rights, democratic development, reconciliation, and the International Criminal Court. Chronologically ordered by year.

Contains alphabetically organized publications primarily from U.S. sources, including university law reviews. Most include information and opinions on restoring judicial systems and practices in the U.S. and internationally following periods of political and armed conflict.
Subdivided into Handbooks and Guides, and Collected Papers, Essays, and Lectures.

Consists of handbooks, guides, field manuals, and sourcebooks related to human rights, including torture and the death penalty. Also includes materials that serves as guides for procedures and management.

did.unittitle: Carr Center for Human Rights Policy. Fellows Program, 2004-2005: Working Papers. Cambridge: Harvard University, 2005.
Henkin, Alice H., ed. The Legacy of Abuse: Confronting the Past, Facing the Future. New York: The Aspen Institute and New York University School of Law, 2002.

Kaufman, Michael, et al. Worldly Conversations: Perspectives from Globetrotters: A Series of Dialogues from the 2002-2003 Season at the Vernon Center. New York: The Lillian Vernon Center for International Affairs at New York University, 2003.

scopecontent.p: Contains files of multiple topics on human rights and international justice, including genocide, children's and women's rights, refugees, democratic process and elections, truth commissions, international prosecutions, and the International Criminal Court. Arranged in alphabetical order by topic.

scopecontent.p: Includes reports from UNIFEM, the Open Society Institute and others. Work focuses on women's rights, women in conflict situations, AIDS, and women's opportunities

scopecontent.p: Contains information packets, assemblies of state parties documents in 2003, and information on coalition members.

scopecontent.p: Includes opinions on the challenges facing the ICC, progress reports on the implementation of the Rome Statute as well as information related to the Victims and Witnesses Unit.

scopecontent.p: The section includes publications on a wide range of issues; a considerable portion come from organizations such as the International Peace Academy, the United Nations, and FRIDE.

Contains articles that discuss the development of international criminal trials and the evidence used in those trials. Also contains a report on a working visit of the special court of Sierra Leone as well as a report on torture and state accountability.

scopecontent.p: Contains documents that discuss rule of law, the legitimacy of terrorism, the "ticking bomb" scenario, and a report by the United Nations on new challenges and threats to peace.
Packets containing pamphlets relating to Peru and South Africa Truth Commissions.

scopecontent.p: Divided into subdivisions for Africa, Asia, Europe, North America, and Latin America. Each geographic area contains newspapers, journal articles and other publications related to governance, rule of law, and political stability. Organized within major divisions with a multi-regional/country section first, followed by country files in alphabetical order. A few publications are in the French language.
Contains work on West Africa and also issues related to security, poverty, and war crimes. Materials include journals, workshop reports, and NGO publications.

Topics cover community service, agriculture, the post-presidential election period of March to May 2002, youth militia training; includes a working draft constitution.

scopecontent.p: Consists of many reports on rule of law, human rights, transitional government, and government reform. Noteworthy authors of the documents are the U.N., the International Crisis Group, the United States Institute of Peace, and the Center for American Progress.

Consists primarily of work by the Aboriginal Healing Foundation on residential schools, survivors of the Canadian residential school system, aboriginal sex offending, and a report on the Aboriginal Healing Foundation itself.

Includes works on human rights, education, the war on terror, the 1898 Wilmington Race Riot and the ensuing Truth and Reconciliation Commission.
Issues from the Latin American Studies Association, LASA Forum, and Kawsaq

scopecontent.p: Contains information on China's presence in Latin America, the issues of integration and fragmentation, MERCOSUR, security, judicial reform, social reform, and new populist and leftist movements.

Includes productions from the Washington Office on Latin America, the Columbia University Institute of Latin American Studies, and the Centro de Derechos Humanos about human rights, conflict situations, enhancing judicial independence, and U.S. military programs in Latin America.

scopecontent.p: Contains monthly reports, comments on international conferences, coordination of institutions working on exile-return, and information on special investigations

Consists of reports on several laws relating to programs for Chilean exiles and returnees, including the establishment of a self-employment program, provisional benefits, exemptions for taxes, the modification of the customs tariff, and amnesty.
Includes information on the health care system and the care of persons affected by political state repression
Information primarily relates to reparations and reconciliation, but also on torture and the Ministry of Justice. Newspaper clippings included.
Consists of work from the Colombian government, the UN, and NGOs. The focus is on establishing peace, reintegrating demobilized combatants, freedom of expression, and human rights in general.

scopecontent.p: Three issues, dating from April to August, 2002

scopecontent.p: Includes work on education, justice, peacebuilding, and bulletins from the Comisión

scopecontent.p: Accession (2009-0193) (76 lin. ft) includes country files, staff files, audiovisual materials, the Mena survey, ICTJ publications, miscellaneous publications, institutional materials, CPU materials, Documentation Center materials, Historical Memory Project and Policymakers Retreat files, and other miscellaneous materials.

processinfo.p: This accession has not been processed or reboxed, but a folder list is available below. Materials may exist in multiple copies. Please contact Research Services to request help in accessing these materials.

accessrestrict.p: RESTRICTED. For more information, contact the reference archivist.
